title: 106_hr781
content:
The Act titled "Job Access and Work Incentives Act" includes a section on preference for contractors hiring welfare recipients. The "Job Access and Work Incentives Act" requires federal agencies to give preference to contractors who agree to hire welfare recipients for jobs created under the contract. The evaluation of offers will prioritize entities that commit to hiring more welfare recipients. Exceptions include cases where national security concerns or the absence of entry-level jobs justify not applying this requirement. Entry-level jobs are expected to be created to carry out contracts exceeding $500,000 by federal agencies. A welfare recipient is defined as someone receiving assistance under a state program funded by the Social Security Act. Title II of the document focuses on Job Access and Reverse Commute Grants, specifically addressing the provision of grants for job access and reverse commute initiatives. Section 3037(l)(1) of the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century is amended to allocate $500,000,000 for fiscal years 2000 to 2004. Subparagraphs (B) and (C) are also amended to specify funding amounts for fiscal years 1999 and beyond. The curr_chunk states that $100,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 1999. TITLE III--GUARANTEES OF LOANS MADE BY STATES TO CURRENT OR RECENT WELFARE RECIPIENTS. $100,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 1999. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide loan guarantees to States up to $50,000,000 annually. The amount of guarantees per State is based on a ratio of total payments under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide loan guarantees to States for loans made by the State to recipients of assistance under a State program funded under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. The loan amount must be between $20 and $5,000, with interest not exceeding the rate on bonds issued by the smallest political subdivision in the borrower's State. The term "State" is defined as in the Social Security Act, and regulations will be set by the Secretary. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to carry out this section. TITLE IV--SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES

Appropriations of $2,730,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 for substance abuse and mental health services. 

TITLE V--RESTORATION OF DEDUCTIONS

Restoration of deduction for business meals, entertainment, and travel expenses for spouses accompanying the taxpayer on business. Restoration of Deduction for Business Meals and Entertainment: Subsection (n) of section 274 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing only 50 percent of meal and entertainment expenses as a deduction, is repealed. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Repeal of Special Limitation on Deduction for Travel Expenses of Spouses: Subsection (m) of section 274 is amended by striking paragraph (3). Effective for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 1999.
